title: German submarine U-861
text:
German submarine "U-861" was a long-range <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine">Type IXD2</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built for <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. <a href="Keel%20laying">Laid down</a> in <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a> and <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 29 April 1943. She was equipped with two stern <a href="torpedo%20tubes">torpedo tubes</a> and 24 <a href="naval%20mine">mines</a>.
She was commanded throughout her service life by "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" <a href="J%C3%BCrgen%20Oesten">Jürgen Oesten</a> (<a href="Knight%E2%80%99s%20Cross%20of%20the%20Iron%20Cross">Knight's Cross</a>).
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXD">German Type IXD2 submarines</a> were considerably larger than the original <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine">Type IX</a>s. "U-861" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. The U-boat had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN</a> M 9 V 40/46 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> four-stroke, nine-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s plus two <a href="MWM%20GmbH">MWM</a> RS34.5S six-cylinder four-stroke diesel engines for cruising, producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> 2 GU 345/34 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-861" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and two at the stern), 24 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="10.5%20cm%20SK%20C/32%20naval%20gun">SK C/32 naval gun</a>, 150 rounds, and a <a href="3.7%20cm%20Flak%2018/36/37/43">Flak M42</a> with 2575 rounds as well as two <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft guns with 8100 rounds. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of fifty-five.
Service history.
She joined <a href="4th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">4th Flotilla</a> for training on 2 September 1943, where she remained until 31 March 1944. She then joined <a href="12th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">12th Flotilla</a> for active service until 30 September 1944. For her last assignment, she joined <a href="33rd%20U-boat%20Flotilla">33rd Flotilla</a>, as part of <a href="Monsun%20Gruppe">Monsoon Group</a> operating out of <a href="Penang">Penang</a> in the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, on 1 October 1944 until the end of the war.
On her final long trip back to Norway carrying vital supplies from the Far East, she struck an iceberg south of Greenland, but reached Trondheim safely on 19 April 1945, with very little fuel remaining.
Fate.
"U-861" surrendered on 9 May 1945 at <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a>, Norway. She was transferred to <a href="Lisahally">Lisahally</a>, Northern Ireland, shortly afterwards.
She was sunk by the Royal Navy on 31 December 1945 in position as part of <a href="Operation%20Deadlight">Operation Deadlight</a>.
